An Ultra low-fat diet restrict the consumption of fat to under 10% of consumed calories.
Generally, a low-fat diet provides around 30% of its calories as fat.
Many students have shown that this diet is ineffective for weight loss in the long term. Proponents of the ultra low-fat diet claim that traditional low-fat diets are not low-fat enough and fat intakes need to stay under 10% of total calories to produce health benefits and weight loss.

How it works:


An ultra low-fat diet contains 10% or fewer calories from fat. The diet is mostly plant-based and has a limited intake of animal products.
Therefore , it is generally very high in carbs (80%) and low in protein (10%)


Weight loss:
 
This diet has beeen shown to be vary sucessful for weight loss among obese individuals. In one study, obese individuals lost an average of 63kg on an ultra low-fat diet termed the rice diet


Other benefits:
 
Ultra low fat diet can improve severeal risk factors for heart disease, including high blood pressure, high cholestrol and markers of inflammation. 
It also can lead to significant improvements in type 2 diabetics.


The downside:
 
The fat restriction may cause problems in the long-term, as fat has many important roles in the body. 
These include helping build cell memberanes and hormones and helping the body absorb fat-soluble vitamins. moreover, an ultra low-fat diet limits the intake of many healthy foods, lacks variety and is extremely hard to stick to.


Cooking tips:
 
*Avoid deep fries
 
*Use herbs or no-oil marinades to flavour foods
 
*Steam vegetables
 
*Bake, broil, boil, poach or roast poultry, fish and lean meats
 
*Add little or no fat to foods
